sample.title: How London‚Äôs Stock Exchange Lost Its Listings
sample.description:
This year has been dismal for London‚Äôs initial public offerings market. A number of high-profile companies have chosen to list elsewhere, fundraising has been at 30-year lows and in September it slipped out of the world‚Äôs top 20 listing destinations. 

How did one of the world‚Äôs most storied exchanges and Europe‚Äôs biggest equity market begin to lose its appeal as an IPO hotspot? We look at the factors contributing to London‚Äôs stalling market and what reforms are planned to try and address it.

sample.description:
Taco Bell is a longtime fast food giant with experts crediting its success to continual innovation. One of its latest undertakings is with beverages ‚Äî joining competitors, like McDonald‚Äôs and Wendy‚Äôs, in ramping up drink innovation. Taco Bell has begun renovating some of its stores into Live M√°s Caf√© with expanded offerings, including specialty coffees and energy drinks. CNBC visited one of the first locations in Irvine, California. Watch the video to learn more about why Taco Bell is betting on beverages.

sample.title: How Costco quietly built a multibillion-dollar clothing empire
sample.description:
Costco has become one of the world‚Äôs biggest clothing retailers. From 2019 to 2024, it grew its annual apparel segment sales from $7 billion to $9.7 billion, a nearly 40% increase, according to estimates by GlobalData.

While the apparel segment is still a relatively small portion of Costco‚Äôs overall sales, it brings in more though its offering of popular brands and private label Kirkland Signature than some of the world‚Äôs largest apparel retailers like Abercrombie & Fitch and Old Navy.

sample.title: How The S&P 500 Quietly Became An AI Fund
sample.description:
The S&P 500 index has long been a go-to investment for those seeking broad market exposure, but that may be changing. AI-fueled growth in companies like Nvidia, Microsoft and Apple has given them outsized influence, with the top five companies now making up nearly 30% of the index. Watch the video above to learn how artificial intelligence is transforming the makeup of the S&P 500, what that means for investors and whether your retirement portfolio is more concentrated than you think.

sample.title: We Saw A New AI-Piloted Fighter Drone About To Transform Warfare
sample.description:
Multiple startups all the way to defense giants like Lockheed Martin are betting that a new generation of advanced drones will define the future of warfare. Shield AI gave CNBC an exclusive first look at the X-BAT, its new AI-powered fighter jet. The company has quickly become a rising force in defense technology, reaching a $5.3 billion valuation after raising $240 million in its latest funding round. Still, it‚Äôs competing against established defense primes like Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman ‚Äî and has yet to turn a profit. Watch the video to see how Shield AI is trying to stand out in a crowded field.

sample.title: Could AI become conscious?
sample.description:
The societal debate surrounding AI companions isn‚Äôt just about their effects on humans. Increasingly it‚Äôs about whether the companions can have human-like experiences.

In a research paper, titled ‚ÄúTaking AI Welfare Seriously,‚Äù Robert Long, the executive director of Eleos AI, and his colleagues argued that ‚Äúthere is a realistic possibility that some AI systems will be conscious and/or robustly agentic in the near future.‚Äù

sample.title: Squawk Pod: Working through the shutdown: the CPI report  - 10/24/25 | Audio Only
sample.description:
Well over 3 weeks into the government shutdown, economists are eager for federal metrics that help paint a picture of our nation‚Äôs economy. To that end, the Labor Department brought back some workers from the Bureau of Labor Statistics to release the Consumer Price Index, or CPI. 10 days late, CNBC‚Äôs Rick Santelli, Nomura‚Äôs David Seif and Richard Bernstein Advisors‚Äôs Michael Contopoulos dig into the numbers and what they mean for the data-driven Federal Reserve. It‚Äôs the second-longest shutdown in U.S. history, and lawmakers like House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-New York) and Senator James Lankford (R-Oklahoma) are standing firm on their respective sides of the standoff. Both explain their perspectives on how the country can move forward. Plus, Target announced it would be laying off about 8% of its corporate workforce, and President Trump says he‚Äôs halted trade negotiations with Canada over an Ontario ad featuring President Ronald Reagan criticizing tariffs. 

In this episode:
James Lankford, @SenatorLankford
Hakeem Jeffries, @RepJeffries
Rick Santelli, @RickSantelli
Joe Kernen, @JoeSquawk 
Becky Quick, @BeckyQuick
Andrew Ross Sorkin, @andrewrsorkin
Katie Kramer, @Kramer_Katie

sample.title: Is climate change to blame for rise in South Korea fishermen deaths? | BBC News
sample.description:
In South Korea, there‚Äôs been a drastic spike in the number of fishermen being killed at sea.
 
Last year more than a hundred died after their boats capsized or sank.
 
The government has investigated, and it has pinpointed climate change as one of the main causes, alongside other factors, like the country‚Äôs ageing workforce.
 
The waters around Korea are warming far faster than the global average. This is causing fish to migrate - forcing fishermen to travel further and take bigger risks to catch enough. 

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#SouthKorea #Fishing #BBCNews

sample.title: Bodies of Palestinians returned by Israel show signs of torture, say doctors in Gaza | BBC News
sample.description:
Doctors at Gaza‚Äôs Nasser Hospital say the bodies of Palestinians returned by Israel under the US-backed ceasefire show signs of torture and abuse, and a lack of resources is making it difficult to identify them.
 
Photographs released by Gaza's medical authorities show some of the bodies badly decomposed, and arriving in civilian clothes or naked except for underwear, some with multiple signs of injury. Many have their wrists tied behind their backs, and doctors say some bodies arrived blindfolded or with cloth roped around their necks.
 
The forensic team at Nasser Hospital are working with almost no resources to answer vast questions about torture, mistreatment and identity - and a lack of cold storage space.
 
Israel‚Äôs army has repeated that it operates in accordance with international law.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog
